banner.description: Track the real-time air quality levels on the go with our smallest, portable, and handiest pocket air monitor.

qualitativeFeatures.description: This air quality monitor helps you to track real-time CO2 levels wherever you go indoor & outdoor. Our pocket sized monitor is the slimmest and handy device that you can easily fit into your pocket.

portableMonitor.imageAlt: prana air portable pocket co2 monitor

userInterfaces.heading: Multiple User-Interfaces
userInterfaces.description: Displaying the real-time CO2 levels in the form of both the emoticon and numerical screens. Green, yellow, and red color representation.

faceNumber.imageAlt: prana air co2 monitor face and number screen

numberScreen.imageAlt: prana air co2 monitor number screen

faceScreen.imageAlt: prana air co2 monitor face screen

graphScreen.imageAlt: prana air co2 monitor graph screen

remoteData.description: AQI data cloud storage eases the accessibility of the monitors air quality data remotely anytime anywhere wherever you go.

co2Monitor.alt: prana air pocket co2 monitor wifi enabled

mobileApp.text: CO2 data on AQI mobile app

aqiApp.description: Connect your Prana Air Pocket CO2 monitor to AQI mobile app to track your CO2 levels in real time and ventilation score.

healthAdvice.title: Health Advice
healthAdvice.description: Get the health advice for indoor CO2 level from AQI app

ventilationScore.title: Ventilation Score
ventilationScore.description: You will understand how good or bad the CO2 levels are in your house.
ventilationScore.imageAlt: co2 vantilation score data on aqi app

historicData.title: Historic Data
historicData.description: You can analyse the historic data of CO2 where you keep the monitor.

monthlyInsight.title: Monthly Insight
monthlyInsight.description: The CO2 level of a whole month can be analysed on your fingertips
monthlyInsight.imageAlt: Prana Air co2 monitor calender monthly data

historic.title: Historic air quality graphs of CO2 level

aqiDashboard.dashboardImageAlt: prana air pocket co2 monitor on aqi web-dashboard

control.title: Control the TV app from mobile.

ventilationScore.title: The data indicates the ventilation score.

aqiTvApp.dashboardImageAlt: prana air pocket co2 monitor on aqi tv-dashboard

install.title: 1. INSTALL AQI APP & SIGN UP
install.description: Install the AQI app on your smartphones from the app store. Sign up & log in through your account.

connect.title: 2. CONNECT THE DEVICE WITH THE APP
connect.description: Go to My Device & select Pocket PM2.5 Monitor. Long press the power button on top of the device until a QR code appears on the screen.

scan.title: 3. SCAN THE QR & CONFIGURE WIFI
scan.description: Scan the QR code or Enter the device ID displayed on your device screen. Fill in your Wi-Fi details. Your device should successfully be connected now.

data.title: 4. NOW GET THE INSIGHTFUL DATA-
data.description: Analyse the PM2.5 level in real-time & historical data stored in the AQI cloud through the app on your smartphone.

download.description: Integrate your monitors data to our mobile application to access the data remotely and analyze the historical trend.

productSlider.description: Our monitor detects CO2 levels at ±5 % accuracy with the help of an in-built NDIR sensor. The product has a 400 mAh battery with 30 minutes (approx.) charging time. It can measure the CO2 range up to 9999 ppm.

ndirTechnology.imageAlt: prana air ndir sensor for pocket co2 monitor
ndirTechnology.description: With Prana Airs CO2 sensor is based on the non-dispersive infrared (NDIR) principle, which is the most widely used and trusted technology for CO2 sensing.

co2HealthIndex.heading: CO2 Health Index
co2HealthIndex.description: The CO2 health index will help you understand the quality of the air you breathe and the health impacts. You will also know if your house or office ventilation system is good or bad.

applications.heading: Applications of CO2 Monitor
applications.description: Based on the dense CO2 concentrations that can be present indoors, Prana Air Pocket CO2 monitor can have various indoor applications like home, school, office, etc. The below cases are on a condition when any fresh air machine or proper ventilation system is not facilitated.

moderate.title: Moderate CO2 At Home – Morning
moderate.description: Usually, at the beginning of the day, the CO₂ levels will range from good to moderate in the early morning.

good.title: Good CO2 At Home – Morning
good.description: When there is proper ventilation and the number of people inside a house is minimal, CO2 levels remain under the good category.

bad.title: Bad CO2 At Home – Evening
bad.description: Usually, at the beginning of the day, the CO₂ levels will range from good to moderate in the early morning.

moderate.title: Moderate CO2 in School – Morning
moderate.description: Usually, the CO2 level in the early morning is moderate when the number of students and staff is not much. The range increases when the number of students and staff increases.
moderate.healthImpacts: Health Impacts: lifelong respiratory infections, unattentiveness, etc.

good.title: Good CO2 in School – Evening
good.description: As the school day ends, there is a progressive decline in the number of students on the school grounds. When the ventilation rate is good, CO2 levels start to decline and the air quality begins to improve.
good.healthImpacts: Health Impacts: Cognitive, IQ skills, mental abilities of the child

bad.title: Bad CO2 in School – Day (Afternoon)
bad.description: An increase in the CO2 levels even by 100 ppm corresponds to a 0.2% increase in absence rates.
bad.healthImpacts: Health Impacts: Cognitive, IQ skills, mental abilities of the child

moderate.title: Moderate CO2 in Office – Morning
moderate.description: Early in the morning, when working hour begins, CO2 levels are typical to moderate as the employees are not fully present.
moderate.healthImpacts: Health Impacts: Employees feel fresh and active when there are good to moderate CO2 levels.

good.title: Bad CO2 in Office – Day (Afternoon)
good.description: As all the employees are present, then CO2 levels rise as a result of respiration and accumulate over time, they are in an unhealthy range.
good.range: CO2 Range: It can exceed up to 3000 ppm
good.healthImpacts: Health Impacts: Dizziness, loss of coordination, unattentiveness

bad.title: Bad CO2 in School – Day (Afternoon)
bad.description: An increase in the CO2 levels even by 100 ppm corresponds to a 0.2% increase in absence rates.
bad.healthImpacts: Health Impacts: Cognitive, IQ skills, mental abilities of the child

placesHighCO2.heading: Places Where There is High CO2 Level
placesHighCO2.description: It helps you understand the level of Carbon Dioxide of your location. Works as both – real-time indoor and outdoor CO2 monitoring sensor; the LCD display shows you CO2 reading indicating

home.title: Home
home.description: CO2 monitoring becomes necessary since different age groups are present in a typical house setting. High CO2 concentrations have diverse effects on different age groups. Children and the elderly are particularly affected. If you have pets, the high levels of CO2 will also harm them. To prevent carbon dioxide poisoning in you, your children, the elderly, and your pets, you can ensure that the desired levels of CO2 are maintained within your homes.

schools.title: Schools
schools.description: Besides our homes, we spend the majority of our time indoors at schools /offices. CO2 levels are generally greater in both classrooms and business settings. When students and staff are exposed to high CO2 levels, they may become drowsy, tired, and lose attention, resulting in poor academic and overall performance. The staffs thinking abilities are also hampered.

malls.title: Malls
malls.description: The indoor air quality and ventilation rates of a building are monitored with the help of a CO2 monitor. There is a constant movement of people inside malls and shop establishments. When a few of them depart, new people enter. As a result, contaminants like carbon dioxide accumulates in malls and retail stores. Monitoring CO2 levels in the retail sector is therefore much more crucial in light of this.

hospitals.title: Hospitals
hospitals.description: According to a 2011 Infinium Medical, Inc. study, 82% of critical care accidents that resulted in brain damage and death might have been avoided if CO2 had been monitored and the necessary steps are taken to lower the excessive levels. Monitoring CO2 levels is frequently overlooked when managing the hospits indoor air quality. When these levels are kept in check, recovery time and attention problems improve.

restaurants.title: Restaurants
restaurants.description: Monitoring CO2 will be helpful since increased CO2 exhalation by residents increases the risk of viral transmission (such as covid-19). On a smart LCD TV screen, the real-time CO2 levels can be displayed. Checking the AQI of hotels and restaurants will be made easier with the help of monitoring. Staff productivity will rise as a result of ongoing CO2 monitoring.

metroSubways.title: Metro Subways
metroSubways.description: Monitoring CO2 levels offer a helpful measure of how well-ventilated inhabited indoor spaces are. These places include airports and metro subways, where the population is fluid and people are constantly arriving and departing, especially during peak hours. To protect public health, it is necessary to continuously monitor interior air pollutant levels in subway stations and airports, where the accumulation of pollutants is very easy.
metroSubways.imageAlt: high co2 level in metro subways

cleanAirSolution.description: Prana Air provides the solution to indoor air pollution with an air purifying machine to purify the air pollutants.

good.name: Good
good.tooltip: The air is fresh and free from toxins. People are not exposed to any health risk.

moderate.name: Moderate
moderate.tooltip: Indoor CO2 levels with a good ventilation rate

poor.name: Poor
poor.tooltip: Tiredness, laziness, and stuffiness in the air

unhealthy.name: Unhealthy
unhealthy.tooltip: Lack of concentration, sleepiness, drowsiness, headaches, increased heart rate, stuffiness in the air, nausea, etc. can be experienced.

severe.name: Severe
severe.tooltip: Many countries have occupational exposure (like an eight-hour TWA).

hazardous.name: Hazardous
hazardous.tooltip: Such high levels of exposure can cause acute oxygen shortage, unconsciousness, severe neurological damage, and even death.
